{"content":"The following is the commit files that have changed: [
  {
    "sha": "2125c0eba0a4dd0bc185d93dbf87ec74119996da",
    "filename": "docs/id-governance/check-workflow-execution-scope.md",
    "status": "modified",
    "additions": 1,
    "deletions": 1,
    "changes": 2,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/df8cefcacee6d74fdccc79f590cf23d887e73379/docs%2Fid-governance%2Fcheck-workflow-execution-scope.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/df8cefcacee6d74fdccc79f590cf23d887e73379/docs%2Fid-governance%2Fcheck-workflow-execution-scope.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fid-governance%2Fcheck-workflow-execution-scope.md?ref=df8cefcacee6d74fdccc79f590cf23d887e73379",
    "patch": "@@ -35,7 +35,7 @@ To check the users who fall under the execution scope of a workflow, you'd follo\n     :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/check-workflow-execution-scope/execution-user-scope-list.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of users under scope of workflow execution.\" lightbox=\"media/check-workflow-execution-scope/execution-user-scope-list.png\":::\n \n > [!NOTE]\n-> The workflow engine routinely evaluates the users that meet the execution conditions regardless of whether they have already been processed by the workflow. The results will not be up to date if the execution conditions have been changed recently, relevant attributes on the user have been changed recently, or the time based trigger has recently passed.\n+> The workflow engine currently has a retroactive window that allows workflows to run for users who previously met the conditions for the workflow. For more information on this window, see: [Lifecycle workflow catch-up window](lifecycle-workflow-execution-conditions.md#lifecycle-workflow-catch-up-window).\n \n ## Check execution user scope of a workflow using Microsoft Graph\n "
  },
  {
    "sha": "e762835f746ef9a43f825ed80780cab15623dec8",
    "filename": "docs/id-governance/lifecycle-workflow-execution-conditions.md",
    "status": "modified",
    "additions": 15,
    "deletions": 4,
    "changes": 19,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/df8cefcacee6d74fdccc79f590cf23d887e73379/docs%2Fid-governance%2Flifecycle-workflow-execution-conditions.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/df8cefcacee6d74fdccc79f590cf23d887e73379/docs%2Fid-governance%2Flifecycle-workflow-execution-conditions.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fid-governance%2Flifecycle-workflow-execution-conditions.md?ref=df8cefcacee6d74fdccc79f590cf23d887e73379",
    "patch": "@@ -79,7 +79,7 @@ When setting a workflow where the trigger type is **Attribute change**, the foll\n \n |Trigger detail  |Description  |\n |---------|---------|\n-|Trigger Attribute     | The trigger attribute defines the attribute that is being changed to trigger the workflow to run.        |\n+|Trigger Attribute     | The trigger attribute defines the attribute that's being changed to trigger the workflow to run.        |\n |Action/Operator     |  Defines the change to the attribute that triggers the workflow to run.       |\n |Value     |  The value of the trigger attribute.      |\n \n@@ -167,11 +167,22 @@ After the execution conditions are set for an enabled workflow, you're able to s\n \n If the execution conditions recently changed for the workflow, then the execution user scope list might not be current. When the execution conditions are recently changed, the list refreshes with users meeting the latest execution conditions after the workflow engine evaluates the users again. Before the workflow runs for the users, it also checks to make sure the list of users still meet the current execution conditions.\n \n-> [!NOTE]\n-> There's currently a catch up window for users based on a 3 day period. This means that when a workflow is created, the workflow engine considers users, who previously met its execution conditions, within 3 days of the scope of the users. For example, if you created a pre-hire workflow to run for users in a certain department 1 week before their hire date, a user who was created within 10 days before their hire date would also fall under the scope of the workflow.\n-\n For a detailed guide on viewing the execution user scope of a specific workflow, see: [Check execution user scope of a workflow](check-workflow-execution-scope.md).\n \n+## Lifecycle workflow catch-up window\n+\n+By design, Lifecycle workflows provide a three day catch up window to help customers process users that could have been missed due to delays in HR user data updates. This means when the workflow engine evaluates users that meet the current execution conditions for the scheduled workflow, it includes users for whom the expected trigger date has already passed but wasn't more than three days past the original trigger date. Once the user is processed, it would only be considered again if there was a change for the user or workflows that allowed it to meet the execution conditions again.\n+\n+The following table shows examples of Lifecycle workflow's catch up window:\n+\n+\n+|Workflow Scenario  |User Data  |Lifecycle workflow behavior  |\n+|---------|---------|---------|\n+|A [pre-hire template](lifecycle-workflow-templates.md#onboard-pre-hire-employee) workflow is scheduled to run for users 7 days before their **EmployeeHireDate**.    |  A user is provisioned by HR in Microsoft Entra ID with an **EmployeeHireDate** in 10 days.      |  The workflow runs for the new user as the date is before the offset.      |\n+|A [pre-hire template](lifecycle-workflow-templates.md#onboard-pre-hire-employee) workflow is scheduled to run for users 7 days before their **EmployeeHireDate**.    | A new user is provisioned by HR in Microsoft Entra ID with an **EmployeeHireDate** in 5 days.      |  The workflow runs for the new user as the date is within 3 days of the offset.      |\n+|A [pre-hire template](lifecycle-workflow-templates.md#onboard-pre-hire-employee) workflow is scheduled to run for users 7 days before their **EmployeeHireDate**.    |  A new user is provisioned by HR in Microsoft Entra ID with an **EmployeeHireDate** in 3 days.     |  The workflow **does not** run for the new user, as the date is more than 3 days from the offset.      |\n+|A new hire workflow runs on Feb 23 for in scope users with **EmployeeHireDate** of Feb 23.    |  A new user is provisioned by HR in Microsoft Entra ID on Feb 24 with an EmployeeHireDate set as Feb 23.      |  The workflow runs again on Feb 24 for the new user, as the date is within 3 days of the offset.     |\n+\n ## Workflow scheduling\n \n While newly created workflows are enabled by default, scheduling is an option that must be enabled manually. To verify whether the workflow is scheduled, you can view the **Scheduled** column on the workflow overview page."
  }
]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary.","role":"user"}
ai_summary.Response:
The documentation for Microsoft Entra ID Lifecycle Workflows has been updated to clarify the behaviour of workflow execution scopes and introduce a detailed explanation of the 'catch-up window'.

One change updates the `check-workflow-execution-scope.md` file to link to a new section on the catch-up window, replacing a general note about retroactive evaluation.

The `lifecycle-workflow-execution-conditions.md` file has been significantly updated. It now includes a dedicated section titled "Lifecycle workflow catch-up window" which elaborates on the three-day window that allows workflows to run for users whose trigger dates may have recently passed. This section also provides examples to illustrate how this window functions in different scenarios, such as pre-hire and new hire workflows. Additionally, a minor edit was made to the description of the 'Trigger Attribute' in the table.
